newsitem.title: USA: USAir plans internal growth, not mergers.
newsitem.headline: USAir plans internal growth, not mergers.

text.p: USAir Group Inc said it plans to expand internally by increasing its international operations, not through mergers or acquisitions.
"Our preference has been for internally-generated growth and that remains our preferred course of action," said USAir Chairman Stephen Wolf.
"We're in no (merger discussion) and we don't see any on the horizon," Wolf said.
USAir, which recently said it will end its code-sharing relationship with British Airways Plc in March 1997, said it expects to eventually pursue other international alliances.
"Long-term we want to participate with somebody, but it's not real high on our radar scope at this time," Wolf said.
USAir, instead, sees "fast, big growth" in its international operations.
The Arlington, Va.-based carrier said it expects to add service to up to 23 international markets from Philadelphia and other key cities within the "next few years."
"We have inherent, fundamental strength to Europe that needs to be exploited," USAir president Rakesh Gangwal said.
In 1997, USAir said it expects domestic growth of about 0.7 percent and total system growth of about 2.0 percent.
USAir said its international expansion is not dependent on the development of a new Anglo-U.S. air treaty.
"Having no 'open skies' deal would not be a big blow; we have a number of other opportunities," said Wolf.
Talks for a new "open skies" agreement between the U.S. and Britain are expected to resume in December.
USAir has filed for access to London Heathrow airport, which could become available if a new U.S.-U.K. air treaty were reached.
Without access to Heathrow, USAir said it could not effectively compete against a proposed pact between British Airways and AMR Corp's American Airlines.
USAir sued British Airways and American over the proposed alliance, saying the deal would lead to a monopoly of air travel between the United States and Britain.
